editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: A COPIE OF A LETter written out of the Hollandors Fleet at ≈øea, the fourth of May. 1607. Stilo Nouo tran≈ølated.
div.p:
BEing vnder the hight of 36. degrees, or afore the riuer of Li≈øbone vpon the tenth of Aprill. our Admirall Iacob Van Hem≈øterk and his coun≈øell determined and fully re≈øolued, to enter into the ≈øaid riuer withall our ≈øhippes to a≈ø≈øaile and ≈øpoile the Caracts & Gallyons lying there, but being certainely aduerti≈øed that the Carackts were gon and that the Gallyons being 8. or 9. were wholy vnrigged & their ordinance on ≈øhoare, ≈øo as it would bee two monthes before they could bee ready, the afore≈øaid re≈øolution was for that time ≈øtaied; & the rather for that diuers Engli≈øh and French ≈øhippes comming out of Saint Lucar & Cales, brought vs certaine newes that not long before their comming forth, fifteene Spani≈øh
≈øhippes of warre of Saint Lucar and Cales, had put to ≈øea and were gone to the ≈øtraights of Gibraltar, being eleuen Gallions and the re≈øt ≈ømaller merchants ≈øhips as then made men of war: Whereupon we re≈øolued to follow and finde theÃÑ out, but the winde being at Ea≈øt, wee met a Flo≈øhinger called Loy Sailemaker that came out of the ≈øtraights the 22. of Aprill and ≈øhewed vs that the night before hee had beene in companie with the Spani≈øh fleete, and that in the morning finding him≈øelfe alone without company, hee ≈øuppo≈øed they had taken their cour≈øe for Cales for with an ea≈øterlie winde they might come out of the ≈øtraights. Vpon the 24. of Aprill the winde comming we≈øterly wee pa≈øt clo≈øe by the barre of Saint Lucar and Bay of Cales, but could not heare that the Gallions had put in ther, for wee were re≈øolued to ≈øet vpon tho≈øe Gallyons that lay within that Bay: But the ≈øame day hauing otherwi≈øe determined wee ≈øailed forwardes to the ≈øtraights of Gibraltar intending to finde out tho≈øe Gallions or Spani≈øh Nauie and to a≈ø≈øaile them. Vpon the 25 of Aprill comming before the towne of Tangier vpon the coa≈øt of Barbary lying in the mouth of the ≈øtraights, and finding the Gallions not there, the Admiral ≈øent for his Coun≈øell abourd his ≈øhippe, where it was re≈øolutely determined, that if the Spani≈øh Nauie were in the Bay of Gibraltar they
would ≈øet vpon them, although it were in their owne hauen and vnder ≈øhot both of the towne and Ca≈øtle, and to end wee tooke order in what ≈øort to a≈ø≈øaile them, which was fir≈øt our Admirall with Captaine Lambert Hindrick≈øon of Rotterdam being Rereadmirall ≈øhould ≈øet vpon and bourd the Spani≈øh Admirall and our Vice Admirall and Captaine Bras of Horne ≈øhould fight with the Spani≈øh Vice Admirall and ≈øo euery one in order: At la≈øt comming to the Bay of Gibralter and finding the Spani≈øh army there, pre≈øently wee began with Gods helpe to proceede in our re≈øolution in ≈øuch order as time and place required, where wee found 21. ≈øhippes among≈øt which were ≈øome Frenchmen Emdeners and other Merchants ≈øhippes, vpon our approach the Spani≈øh Admira'l wayed Anchor and went neerer the town and lay by foure other Gallions but the Vice admiral lay ≈øtil hauing a bourd 450. men, as the pri≈øoners after certified vs, the Admirall had 100. Caueliers out of the towne that voluntarily came abourd to help him although hee was well prouided of men before, all this notwith≈øtanding and although he had th'aduantage of th'ordnance of the towne and ca≈øtels yet our Admirall and Captaine Lambert of Roterdam valiantly bourded him, and the re≈øt of our ≈øhips a≈øwell as they could ≈øet vpon the re≈øt of the Gallions, and al≈øo vpon the Spani≈øh Vice
Admirall; And after wee had fought in that mo≈øt furious a≈ø≈øault both with ordinance and forceable bourding their Ships 4 howers or thereabouts by Gods helpe we got the victory, all the Gallions being ≈øpoiled batterd and burnt were driueÃÑ on ground & amoÃÑg≈øt the re≈øt the Admiral of 800 tonns, called S. Augu≈øtine wherin the generall called Don Iohn Alveres Dauila borne in A≈øtorga was ≈ølaine, beeing an olde experienced Souldiour that had ≈øerued at Sea in Don Iohn de Au≈øtria his time, al≈øo the Vice Admirall was ≈ølaine and the Coronell of the Souldiors and all the Captaines of their Nauie, the Gallions and the re≈øt of the Spani≈øh ≈øhips were pre≈øently burnt downe to the water, whereof two did driue on ≈øhore but ≈øo ≈øpoyled that they were altogether vn≈øeruiceable, thi'n ≈øignes, ≈øtreamers and pendants of the Admiral, Vice Admirall and other Gallions we tooke with vs and ≈øome other pillage, but by rea≈øon of the terrible fyer in the Spani≈øh Vice Admirall and other Gallions that were on fire and ranne on ground wee could not bring any Ships or Ordnance away, for we were in great daunger of fire our ≈øelues, & diuers of vs had work enough to do to quench the fire that had gotten into theÃÑ, but God of his mercie pre≈øerued vs. Of all the men in the Spani≈øh armie but fewe e≈øcaped, for the Bond of Gibralter ≈øhewed as if it had bin ≈øowed with
Spaniards that leapt ouer-boord, & tho≈øe that we took confe≈ø≈øed that they were 4000. men in the Nauie. We tooke 50. pri≈øoners, one whereof was the Generalls ≈øonne called Iohn Alueres Dauila Captaine of the Gallion called S Augu≈øtine. In this fight we lo≈øt our valiant Generall Iacob Van Hem≈øterk, who with an honorable and braue re≈øolution vndertooke this fight and with the aide of the Vice Admirall Captaine Lambert of Rotterdam, and Captaine Peter William≈øon brauely ouercame & by gods helpe vanqui≈øhed there enemie. The 26. of Aprill we brought our ≈øhips from before the town and ca≈øtell, for with their continual ≈øhooting they did vs much hurt, and being without their reach wee manned out ≈øome of our boates and ≈øente, them to the burnt ≈øhips which lay vpon the ≈øhore, which the ≈øpaniards on land perceiuing wente them≈øelues to ≈øet thadmiralls ≈øhip on fire, which lay all ≈øhotte and torne vpon the ≈øtrande, and ≈øo they did that which we ment to haue doon. In this fight there was at lea≈øt 8000. greate ≈øhotte di≈øcharged and was hardily & furiou≈øly fought, being fearefull and terrible to behould when the ≈øpani≈øh gallions began to burne, e≈øpecially when fire came to their powder, it ≈øhewed as if newe clouds and lightning had ri≈øen out of the ≈øea and mounted into the skie by a ≈øailer called Gouert an Engli≈øh man but gaue him≈øelfe out for one of
Embden, that was taken pri≈øoner by the Spani≈øh general and ≈øet at liberty vpon our approach to bee adui≈øed and coun≈øelled by him what were be≈øt to bee don: wee were aduerti≈øed that the Admirall would not beleeue wee dur≈øt be ≈øo bold to bourd him in the Kings Bay or hauen, and e≈øpecially vnder the ≈øhot of the towne and Ca≈øtle of Gibraltar, which contrary to their expectation wee made them feele. The Spani≈øh Generall had certaine aduice before of our comming how many ≈øhippes of warre wee had and with prouant ≈øhippes and Souldiours. Among≈øt other thinges that wee tooke wee found the Kinges ≈øecret in≈øtructions ≈øigned with the King of Spaines owne hand Ioel Rey whereby we perceiue what vnaccu≈øtomed tyranny the ≈øaid King had commaunded him to execute and to torment the naturall borne inhabitantes of the nether lands e≈øpecially the Hollanders and Zelanders and all their adherents, ≈øo that other nations by this comm ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øion were not altogether exempted. The 27. of Aprill wee ≈øet ≈øaile and put out of the bay of Gibraltar, and made toward the coa≈øt of Barbary, fir≈øt going to Chuta and entered ≈øo far into that bay that they ≈øhotte at vs both from the towne and other places of the ≈øhore, there the Portugalles in great numbers gott vppon their hor≈øes, fearing to bee dealt withall as they were at Gibraltar: but becau≈øe of the vnfitnes and bad
≈øecurity of the place, we ≈øayled further to the bay of Titnan five Miles from Chuta to rigge our ≈øhips for that many of them were vnfurni≈øhed of Bore≈øprits, Ma≈øts, Sailes, Cordage and other things, and had beene ≈øhotte through and fired in bourding the Spani≈øh Gallions: and comming beefore Titnan (a place vnder the Turks and Moores commaund) wee were very welcome vnto them; and vpon the 28. of April the gouernor with many Turki≈øh geÃÑtlemen came abourd our ≈øhips bidding vs welcome offering vs all favour and friend≈øhip hee could aforde vs, and to aide vs withall wee ≈øtoode in neede off for our wounded men or otherwi≈øe: hee and all his company and country ≈øeeming to bee glad of the victory which (by Gods helpe) we had obtained again≈øt the Spaniards. The fourth of May at Titnan ≈øixe miles from Chuta vpon the coa≈øt of Barbary wee new rigged and prepared our ≈øhips (which were ≈øore battred) of all nece≈ø≈øaries, ≈øtaying Gods plea≈øure for an Ea≈øterly winde to pa≈ø≈øe the ≈øtraights, and once againe to ≈øeeke after our enemies, deuiding our Fleet into foure ≈øquadrons, the Admirall beeing accompanied with ≈øeuen other ≈øhippes of warre and the like in euery ≈øquadron. The Admirall Moun≈øieur Hem≈øterk that was ≈ølaine was a very wi≈øe and well experienced man, who with greate paine, labour and indu≈øtry had beene twice in the could
Streights of Weygattes, and at the Ea≈øt Indies, where in his la≈øt voyage he ouercame and took the great rich Carackts comming from Malacho in China, with whome of good will and affection toward him many men ventured their liues in this voyage, as among≈øt others Ioris Van Spilberg that hath beene both in the Ea≈øt and We≈øt Indies and imployed in this Fleete as Commi≈øary, and one of the Coun≈øell of warre, generall captaine of the Zeland Souldiers, and diuer≈øe other captaines.
